question: Have you ever bought shoes online?
transcript: I actually have, like, I bought like a pair of British Hunter when the new product was released in 2017. you know, at first everything seemed fine and good, but then when I received the package, it turns out that my, I, my shoes did not fit me and it was too tight and all because I did not, pick the right food size. So, I mean, it was not a, it was not a pleasant experience for me. So. So I would have to be more careful next time How much money do you usually spend on shoes so because like they are not my cup of tea so I have like a very limited budget for them Like roughly about 1 to 2 million Vietnam dong for a pair of good sneakers and maybe less than a million for the sandals And of course I have to wait for the sales season to come to wrap me up a pair too Okay, what do you prefer, fashionable shoes or comfortable shoes? Okay, so as I mentioned earlier, I opt for comfort. So, you know, like trendy shoes cannot have my, capture my attention. And, you know, like what is the point of like wearing a good looking shoes when you, your feet are aching and hurting, you know.

anti_overrating.reason: 'pick the right food size' (foot size). 'wrap me up a pair' (grab me a pair? wrap up usually means finish). 'wearing a good looking shoes' (a pair of good looking shoes / good looking shoes).

ielts_descriptor_alignment.vocabulary_text: Uses less common and idiomatic vocabulary skilfully.

question: What is your opinion on this?
transcript: this may sound weird, but I agree with them. Okay, call me old-fashioned or whatever, but I think that life back then was so much easier than it is now. You know, back then, before, we lived closely together. We blended in with the nature, you know, living on the hill next to a farm, the river. Everything was so serene, compared to the society now. You know, like, with the, introduction of technology or the integration of industrialization, everything just so hectic and we had barely had a room to breathe.

anti_overrating.reason: 'everything just so hectic' (everything is just so hectic). 'we had barely had a room' (we barely have room / we barely had room).

ielts_descriptor_alignment.vocabulary_text: Uses language with natural and sophisticated control of lexical features.

question: Why do people often miss their childhood?
transcript: Personally I think like, there are always two sides of a story. Not everyone growing up like, you know, reminiscing about their precious childhood. You know, some may grow up with like, emotional scars while developing. So, but the only one thing that they all comes back for is the void that they are having now. For example, like, you know, like the, Fun family reunion in Ted's holiday, like the lucky money you get for Ted, or like the first love kiss under the rain, and the list goes on. You know, all of those precious moments like imprinted on their mind forever to remind them of the time that they were happy as best.

anti_overrating.reason: 'they all comes back for' (come back). 'Ted's holiday' (Tet holiday - transcription error likely, but context implies Tet). 'happy as best' (happiest? happy at best?).

ielts_descriptor_alignment.vocabulary_text: Uses less common and idiomatic vocabulary skilfully.

question: So how do people record their good memories?
transcript: There is a lot of means, I will say. The most common one would be pictures. You know, people tend to take pictures, Polaroids, or keeping precious moments in, like, photographs so they can have something to look back at. And, you know, and of course, in forms of, like, pictures, people can share it online to the social media with their friends in a vibrant and realistic way so that everyone can visualize what the scenery or the view is about. That is the end of the test.

anti_overrating.reason: 'There is a lot of means' (There are a lot of means).

ielts_descriptor_alignment.vocabulary_text: Uses less common and idiomatic vocabulary skilfully.

question: Do you have a lot of close friends?
transcript: I would not say close, but I have many friends right now at the moment. I would say my closest friend is my brother. And I have another friend too, but we are not that close together.

ielts_descriptor_alignment.vocabulary_text: Uses a sufficient range of vocabulary.

question: And how often do you contact your friends?
transcript: Usually, like, I would say almost every day, we are really in contact with each other. We have a group and we message each other a lot there and we send posts and all the other cool stuff.

ielts_descriptor_alignment.vocabulary_text: Uses a sufficient range of vocabulary.

question: And do you think friendship is important?
transcript: Definitely, yes, it is important because, you get lots of, you get to know their information, their, their idea and what they think. They think they can really make you to become a better person.

ielts_descriptor_alignment.grammar_text: Makes some errors in grammar and punctuation.

question: Are you fond of art?
transcript: Actually I really, I am really not into art that much. I do not follow the, I do not follow the painting or like, those kind of stuff that much. But if we say music, I am really into music.

anti_overrating.reason: 'follow the painting' (follow painting / interested in painting).

question: And is it necessary to have art classes in school years?
transcript: It can be very, for example, crucial for children because they can get to know if they are interested in art or not. Some people are, they really do not like, art and, it can be very essential for the children.

ielts_descriptor_alignment.vocabulary_text: Uses a sufficient range of vocabulary.

question: How often do you visit art galleries?
transcript: Actually not that much. Like I said I am really not interested in art. But if, if I, like I would visit it from time to time if a friend asks me to. But myself no, I would not. I would not do that.

ielts_descriptor_alignment.vocabulary_text: Uses a sufficient range of vocabulary.

question: How often do you send text messages to people?
transcript: I rather call people actually because texting, you cannot send emotions based on text. It really matters to me. For example, when someone messages me, I cannot understand if they are angry, if they are happy. I do not understand anything, but when I call them, I feel more comfortable with them.

anti_overrating.reason: 'I rather call' (I'd rather call / I would rather call).

question: Do you prefer to call a person or send him a message?
transcript: Yes, I would rather call people because it is much easier. Personally, it is much easier for me. And especially close friends, I would say.

question: And how has texting and messaging benefited you the most?
transcript: I would say because like it can benefit obviously benefits the entire humanity but for example if I am far away or I am lost I can call a friend or my parents to come and pick me up and it can be very helpful.

ielts_descriptor_alignment.vocabulary_text: Uses a sufficient range of vocabulary.

question: Do you think journeys have become easier due to the use of navigation apps?
transcript: It has become really easier. Obviously I use it a lot. Like, for example, coming to every place, it can really help. But unfortunately, one of the problems of taking navigation from the app or something, it makes you do not remember the addresses. And if you wanted to go to the same place again, you would need to use a navigation again. You would not remember any of the, you would not remember any of the, addresses or the ways.

anti_overrating.reason: 'really easier' (much easier). 'makes you do not remember' (makes you forget / keeps you from remembering).

ielts_descriptor_alignment.grammar_text: Attempts to use complex sentences but these tend to be less accurate.

question: Why do people usually embark on journeys in your country?
transcript: In my country people really like taking journeys. Mostly they would, they would like take cars and cars, they would go with cars. But, I do not, I really, I really encourage people to take journeys. Because it can really be, healthy and you know, you can get your, mind clean about the stress that you have in your life. It can be very, interesting. And you, I do take journey, I have journeys a lot.

anti_overrating.reason: 'taking journeys' (going on journeys / taking trips). 'go with cars' (go by car). 'get your mind clean' (clear your mind). 'have journeys a lot' (travel a lot).

ielts_descriptor_alignment.grammar_text: Makes some errors in grammar and punctuation.

question: And, as travelling has eased, do people nowadays plan their journey routes as compared to the past?
